JANE ALEXANDER: The 1970's, Watergate, Women's
Rights and Vietnam... Tumultuous times catapult

14.text:
Gerald R. Ford and his wife Betty into the
White House. He was plainspoken and she was

20.text:
outspoken.
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: It is impossible to overestimate

26.text:
the impact that Betty Ford had on the office
of first lady. She changes everything about

32.text:
the role of first lady.

37.text:
who are alive right now and in recovery that
wouldn't be there if Mrs. Ford hadn't gone

61.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: This is her story.
In Betty Ford's brief and unexpected reign

85.text:
as first lady she broke the mold. She was
a Pro-Choice Republican who became the first

91.text:
first lady to take on a feminist agenda and
one of the few to differ publicly with her

96.text:
husband.
BETTY FORD: I really always have been probably

100.text:
what you might say is outspoken -- sometimes
to the detriment of my husband's role as president.

109.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: Her ability to be open and
honest about her battles with breast cancer

114.text:
and drug and alcohol abuse, saved millions.
It was an incredible and sometimes painful

122.text:
journey.
In 1947, troops were flocking back home from

135.text:
the war and in Grand Rapids, Michigan the
young and upwardly mobile gathered at Kent

141.text:
Country Club for Saturday night dances. It
was here that hometown belle Betty Bloomer

147.text:
Warren would first spot the young lawyer Gerald
Ford.

150.text:
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: He was a football hero
who had not only been a hero at the University

156.text:
of Michigan but had been drafted by the pros.
He was a bona fide war hero. He was incredibly

162.text:
handsome. He was the type of guy who would
gravitate to a beautiful woman like Betty

168.text:
Bloomer Warren, and he does.
BETTY FORD: We just thought we would be good

175.text:
friends, companions and so many of our friends
were married that it made it handy to have

184.text:
somebody to do things socially with or go
to a movie with but with time I certainly

192.text:
developed a feeling that this was someone
special in my life.

198.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: It was indeed a special relationship
a partnership that would endure for over half

204.text:
a century propelling Betty Bloomer Warren
onto a world stage that would give her the

210.text:
biggest audience of her life.
She was born Elizabeth Anne Bloomer on April

217.text:
8th, 1918. Her two brothers Bill and Bob,
who were 5 and 8 years her senior, called

223.text:
her Betty. They grew up in a fashionable section
of Grand Rapids, Michigan, a small mid-western

229.text:
city.
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: It was the epitome of

231.text:
middle class America.
JANE ALEXANDER: Betty's mother, Hortense Nearh

235.text:
Bloomer, was from a wealthy family. She was
also a perfectionist, whose standards Betty

241.text:
always tried to live up to.
Betty's father, Bill Bloomer worked as a travelling

246.text:
salesman selling conveyor belts.
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: It wasn't a privileged

250.text:
upbringing but it was a comfortable upbringing.
Because of her father's success in sales,

258.text:
they were able to avoid being hurt very badly
by the Great Depression.

263.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: But that success meant Betty's
father was rarely home.

267.text:
BETTY FORD: My mother was a very independent
woman because she had to be. She had been

274.text:
very much a role model in my life because
my father was gone a lot

279.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: The influence of two older
brothers and a strong mother fortified Betty

284.text:
Bloomer's already independent nature.
LILLIAN FISHER: She spoke right out. You always

289.text:
knew how you stood and what she wanted. She
wasn't a namby-pamby pretty little dancing

295.text:
doll. She was very much a solid character.
JANE ALEXANDER: A solid character that became

301.text:
comfortable performing at an early age. At
age eight, Betty Bloomer danced with the Calla

306.text:
Travis Dance Troupe in their spring recitals
and continued dancing through high school.

312.text:
BETTY FORD: I became very interested in my
dancing school. And I spent a lot of time

321.text:
with that because I enjoyed it so much. I
kind of fell in love with dance.

327.text:
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: So she gravitated to modern
dance. Which was an outgrowth of the artistic

335.text:
scene of the 1920's, was much more expressive,
was much more free form. It was perfectly

342.text:
suited for Betty's adventurous personality.
JANE ALEXANDER: Before long Betty was the

346.text:
star of many dance recitals in Grand Rapids.
She even modeled to pay for her dance lessons.

352.text:
LILLIAN FISHER: She was very popular with
the boys. There would be several of us who

357.text:
would sort of wait and see who is asking her
for Friday and Saturday night dates and then

363.text:
see who was going to be left over for us.
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: She dated a great deal,

369.text:
she smoked early. She says she had her first
drink at age 14. This was a young rebel.

375.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: But Betty's teenage fun and
revelry would come to a halt one day when

380.text:
she came home to discover her father had died.
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: He was found in his garage,

385.text:
in the car, with the motor running and he
asphyxiated from carbon monoxide poisoning.

390.text:
BETTY FORD: It came as a shock because he
died quite suddenly. I was 16 years old, which

397.text:
is a very impressionable age, a very important
age.

401.text:
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: What was more important
than how he died was what happened at the

408.text:
funeral when Betty was told for the first
time by her mother that her father was indeed

414.text:
an alcoholic.
JANE ALEXANDER: The revelation of her father's

417.text:
alcoholism would become more significant as
Betty struggled with her own issues later

423.text:
in life. For now, she watched as her mother
carried on with a strength she would try to

428.text:
emulate.
BETTY FORD: She went out and she got her real

431.text:
estate license and sold houses. That gave
me an idea of how independent a woman can

438.text:
be if she needs to be.
JANE ALEXANDER: After high school, Betty went

442.text:
to a summer dance program at Bennington College
in Vermont.

446.text:
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: It was the complete inverse
of Grand Rapids -- very progressive faculty.

453.text:
And Betty found herself and found her artistic
muse in Bennington.

458.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: Betty's muse was modern dance
pioneer Martha Graham who was in residence

465.text:
teaching a summer workshop.
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: Martha Graham wanted the

468.text:
performer to be able to lay everything on
the line in public. There is no better definition

476.text:
of what Betty Ford would become than that.
JANE ALEXANDER: After Bennington, Betty followed

482.text:
Martha Graham to New York, but after two years

489.text:
Martha saw that Betty enjoyed her social life
as well as dance.

492.text:
BETTY FORD: Martha was very strict. She expected
you to give it full attention 24 hours a day.

500.text:
So I had a lot of talkings-to by Martha. You
know if you're really serious about this,

508.text:
you better settle down.
JANE ALEXANDER: Betty decided she wasn't ready

511.text:
to fully commit to the life of a dancer, and
gave into her mother's pleas to come home.

516.text:
BETTY FORD: She kept talking about all my
friends at home who were getting married and

522.text:
having these lovely weddings and trying to
tempt me to come back.

527.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: Betty did return and married
a traveling salesman named Bill Warren, whom

532.text:
she divorced within five years. She supported
herself working as a model and fashion coordinator.

539.text:
And she lived in an apartment on her own.
It was at this time that Yale Law School graduate

546.text:
Gerald Ford and Betty Bloomer Warren would
cross paths.

549.text:
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: He was a perfect match
for Betty Bloomer Warren, who had come back

557.text:
a much more cosmopolitan person from Bennington,
and from New York.

562.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: With her sense of humor, beauty
and sophistication she was the tonic that

568.text:
loosened up this conservative young lawyer
and in turn his serious convictions offered

574.text:
her a stability that both her father and first
husband could not. In a matter of months they

579.text:
were talking about marriage.
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: Gerald Ford was ready

583.text:
to accept his wife as a professional woman.
He was ready to accept her as an outgoing,

590.text:
outspoken woman.
STEVE FORD: But you know, he kept a secret,

594.text:
he didn't tell her he was running for politics,
he says, you know, I want to marry you. But,

597.text:
I've got a secret. I can't tell you till later.
Betty agreed to marry Ford, and soon after

602.text:
he revealed his secret: he planned to run
for Congress, she wasn't thrilled, but though

607.text:
it was unlikely he would win.
STEVE FORD: He was running for Congress in

611.text:
a very conservative Dutch area, you know.
And the idea of him marrying a divorced woman

618.text:
may not go over that well. I mean, that was
politics back in the 1950s.

623.text:
She swears to this day if she knew he was
running for Congress she would have never

628.text:
ever married a politician.
JANE ALEXANDER: Ford won the primary, guaranteeing

633.text:
him the election in his Republican district.
They were married on October 15, 1948, between

640.text:
the primary and the general election.
Betty would get a glimpse into her future

645.text:
as a political wife, when Ford arrived late
to the wedding with muddy shoes from campaigning

651.text:
at a nearby farm.
Janet Ford, the matron of honor, would remark

655.text:
to the new Mrs. Ford, "You won't have to worry
about other women, Jerry's work will be the

661.text:
other women."
RICHARD NORTON SMITH: Their honeymoon consisted

666.text:
of a University of Michigan football game

672.text:
trip up to Owasso, Michigan on a cold October
night in the outdoors to hear Thomas E. Dewey

681.text:
orate. And this was sort of her formal initiation
into the life of a political wife.

689.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: On January 3 1949 newly elected
Congressman Gerald Ford and his wife Betty

700.text:
arrived in Washington.
RICHARD NORTON SMITH: He was this very promising,

704.text:
up and coming athletic, you know, former football
player from a safe seat in Michigan. Who from

710.text:
a very early age in Congress had been noticed
and taken under the wings of the old bulls

717.text:
who ran the place. He was a man who expected
to spend his entire career in the House.

721.text:
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: He was also that very
rare type of politician who was welcomed on

727.text:
either side of the aisle. And he could be
friends, honest friends with Republican and

736.text:
Democrat alike. He was affable. He was likeable.
He was approachable.

742.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: And Betty immersed herself
in the obligations of a political wife.

747.text:
BETTY FORD: It was very exciting for me. I
had never lived in Washington before.

753.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: A year after the Ford's arrived
in Washington, their first son Michael was

758.text:
born.
BETTY FORD: When we brought home that first

762.text:
little boy. I was dumbfounded at the love
and astonishment that my husband had for this

771.text:
little darling creature. He was like melted
butter.

775.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: In rapid succession the Fords
would add Jack, Steve and Susan to the roost

784.text:
and build a modest house in Alexandria, Virginia.
BETTY FORD: I became very much a full time

790.text:
mother. I was very active at the church as
a Sunday school teacher trying to make a good

797.text:
role model for our children.
JANE ALEXANDER: They were a quintessential

802.text:
middle American family one thing set them
apart dad wasn't always home for dinner at

814.text:
five.
MICHAEL BESCHLOSS: He loved his wife, but

816.text:
he was an ambitious politician. He wanted
to be Speaker of the House. One way to do

821.text:
that was to get IOU's from people who you
helped get elected. As a result, he was on

827.text:
the road sometimes 200 days a year. She was
at home with four children, relatively modest

834.text:
household income. That was a very tough thing
for her to live through.

838.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: Betty found herself once again,
with a husband who was on the road as much

842.text:
as her father had been. There was no doubt
that Ford was a loving attentive father when

848.text:
he was home, but the demands of a political
career took their toll.

853.text:
JACK FORD: Because Dad wasn't necessarily
there all the time, she sort of played that

857.text:
dual role of trying to be the mom but also
trying to play some of the dad role. There

862.text:
was no question the burden was greater on
Mother.

864.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: And to make matters worse,
a simple accident while opening a window would

870.text:
set her off on a downward spiral.
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: She was taken to an osteopathic

875.text:
hospital and they diagnosed a pinched nerve.
They dealt with that pinched nerve which was

882.text:
an incredible searing pain with prescription
drugs. Prescription drugs that by her own

889.text:
admission Betty begins to take out of the
prescribed dosage.

896.text:
JACK FORD: The pain would be such that she
was bed ridden, when you're a healthy young

903.text:
kid growing up you understand being hurt but
you don't understand being hurt in a way that

908.text:
doesn't get better. The ability to treat those
kinds of injuries was pretty primitive. Put

915.text:
some hot packs on it. You know take a couple
of pills and that's about all we can do for

919.text:
you.
JANE ALEXANDER: In 1965 Ford became Minority

923.text:
Leader of the House and demands on his time
increased.

926.text:
BETTY FORD: And I would read all these things
about my husband being someplace, great articles,

933.text:
but I realized that I was kind of what I considered
just nobody. I had no self esteem, kind of

946.text:
depression, withdrawal. I really felt that
I was kind of being left behind.

954.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: In her memoirs Betty writes:
"I hated feeling crippled so I took more pills.

962.text:
Now I know that some of the pain I was trying
to wipe out was emotional."

967.text:
One day, Susan came home and found her mother
hysterically crying.

971.text:
SUSAN FORD: It was very scary when she had
a breakdown and I think it was probably the

976.text:
stress of four kids and a husband who wasn't
home and everything else. I know that she

983.text:
was hospitalized.
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: What was happening to

985.text:
her actually mirrors what Betty Friedan was
talking about in the Feminine Mystique.

990.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: Betty Ford mirrored the independent
women in Friedan's book. Published in 1963,

998.text:
it showed women marrying and devoting their
lives to their husbands' careers while burying

1003.text:
their own to ambitions and losing their identities.
Some, unhappy and depressed, turned to drink.

1009.text:
BETTY FORD: One of my doctors suggested I
see a psychiatrist which I did. And we worked

1017.text:
through it as far as my role in my life. He
said you need to take one whole day for Betty

1025.text:
and do whatever you want. Be out with friends
or whatever appeals to you.

1032.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: And Betty returned to what
she loved best -- dance.

1035.text:
BETTY FORD: When I started the modern dance
class with these other women that was kind

1042.text:
of pressure relief. That was the relief valve.
JANE ALEXANDER: But it was not enough, in

1050.text:
her memoirs Betty admits that when Jerry was
away she began a routine of having her, "five

1056.text:
o'clock drink at a neighbor's house another
fixing dinner and then a nightcap watching

1061.text:
television." Something she never discussed
with her psychiatrist.

1064.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: A landslide victory in 1972
put Republican President Richard Nixon back

1074.text:
in the White House but Congress would remain
Democratic dashing Ford's dreams of becoming

1080.text:
House Speaker. Much to Betty's relief, Gerry
began to discuss leaving politics all together.

1087.text:
BETTY FORD: We had plans to retire and we
talked about it and we said well he would

1094.text:
serve out that term with President Nixon and
then we would retire.

1102.text:
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: I think clearly and some
of the children point this out in later interviews,

1108.text:
they saw that their father was now more aware
of how fragile his wife had become. They start

1115.text:
talking about retirement and then Spiro Agnew
changes everything.

1120.text:
PRESIDENT NIXON: I do solemly swear...
JANE ALEXANDER: The triumph of President Nixon's

1130.text:
re-election quickly lost its luster when a
burglary in Democratic National Committee

1135.text:
headquarters at the Watergate ballooned into
televised Senate hearings linking the president's

1142.text:
staff and possibly the President himself to
the break in.

1145.text:
SEN. HOWARD BAKER: What did the President
know and when did he know it.

1151.text:
And while America focused on one scandal another
erupted.

1155.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: On October 10th 1973, Vice
President Spiro Agnew, who had been under

1162.text:
investigation for accepting bribes while Governor
of Maryland, resigned. He was the first Vice

1169.text:
President in American history to do so.
MICHAEL BESCHLOSS: Americans saw their Vice

1173.text:
President taking cash and envelopes in his
office. They saw their President covering

1179.text:
up a burglary and other crimes. These were
things that Americans never could have imagined.

1184.text:
They felt they were really in unchartered
territory.

1187.text:
STEVE FORD: Dad's name was on the list of
maybe ten people that might be selected by

1192.text:
Nixon as the next vice president. I think
we all thought Nixon needed him in Congress

1198.text:
to help get legislation passed.
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: Nixon, who has got his

1201.text:
own Watergate problems at that time goes in
a shrewd move to Capitol Hill. And he says

1206.text:
I want someone who is going to guaranteed
to be approved. And in every poll Gerald Ford

1215.text:
headed the list.
BETTY FORD: I had been in my slacks, usual

1219.text:
getting dinner for the family. My husband
had come home to have dinner and then he was

1226.text:
planning to go back to the White House for
that announcement.

1229.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: It was an ordinary night until...
STEVE FORD: The phone rang at the house and

1234.text:
dad got on the phone. I think General Alexander
Haig was on the other end of that line, letting

1239.text:
dad know that President Nixon was calling
to ask him to be vice president.

1243.text:
RICHARD NORTON SMITH: And it's only then that
Mrs. Ford learns in effect that her whole

1251.text:
life is about to be turned upside down, and
oh by the way in 2 hours you have to be in

1256.text:
the east room of the White House to be introduced

1259.text:
STEVE FORD: I remember my mother saying to
dad. She wasn't crazy about him being Vice

1264.text:
President. She'd just got him ready to resign

don't do anything."
PRESIDENT NIXON: My fellow Americans, I proudly

1275.text:
present to you the man whose name I will submit

as Vice President of the United States, Congressman

1289.text:
BETTY FORD: I was very much in awe of the
situation. This recognition that he was receiving

1298.text:
seemed to just also flow out to me. And I

1306.text:
JOHN ROBERT GREENE: Nixon when it's all over

1313.text:
she looks at him and says, congratulations
or condolences.

1316.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: On Dec. 6, 1973, Ford was

1323.text:
Betty is thrust out of the anonymous role
of congressional wife onto the public stage

1342.text:
while she admitted she was terrified of television
interviews, nevertheless she always spoke

1348.text:
out candidly.
DOUGLAS KIKER: Mrs. Ford, I'll ask you a political

1351.text:
question. How do you stand on the Woman's
Liberation Movement?

1355.text:
BETTY FORD: I would say I am for Women's Lib
because I feel very strongly that/ a woman

1365.text:
should certainly receive equal pay for equal
compensation as any man would. I think I'm

1375.text:
a feminist really.
JACK FORD: People may think that Mother became

1379.text:
an activist when she got to the White House.
But anybody who knew her over the years will

1385.text:
know that she was always one to speak her
mind. She and the rest of the family were

1391.text:
very blessed in that Dad was one of those
people who encouraged people to think for

1397.text:
themselves and he wasn't threatened by it.
JANE ALEXANDER: And the new second family

1405.text:
was a big hit with the media.
DICK CAVETT: Hello I'm Dick Cavett you may

1410.text:
wonder what I'm doing here. I'm right in front
of 514 Crown View Drive and the reason for

1417.text:
that is the man living here suddenly became

1423.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: Cavett was invited in to meet

1427.text:
But the introduction to the Ford family was

1432.text:
PROTESTERS: Impeach Nixon now.
RICHARD NORTON SMITH: People were distrustful

1438.text:
of the political process, cynicism had taken
root, people had been lied to. The country

1446.text:
was coming apart at the seams over an unpopular

1451.text:
HOWARD K. SMITH: On Saturday the house judiciary
committee recommended that President Nixon

1454.text:
be charged with obstructing justice in the

1458.text:
BETTY FORD: We had literally prayed that this

1466.text:
Nixon would continue to serve out his term:
It just began to get bigger and bigger.

JANE ALEXANDER: The final blow would come

to turn over white house tape recordings that

NEWSCASTER: President Nixon stunned the country
today.

1485.text:
NEWSCASTER: The Republican Party today gave

DAN RATHER: White House aides say privately,

JANE ALEXANDER: On August 8th, 1974 a shocked

1501.text:
PRESIDENT NIXON: I shall resign the Presidency
effective at noon tomorrow. Vice President

1508.text:
Ford will be sworn in as President at that
hour in this office.

JANE ALEXANDER: It was an historical first.
The next day, the Fords accompanied Nixon

1519.text:
and his wife Pat, to the helicopter that would

BETTY FORD: It was in my mind the saddest
day of my life. I can't remember when I felt

1538.text:
so totally unable to handle something.

Gerald R. Ford was sworn in as President of
the United States.

1552.text:
PRESIDENT GERALD FORD: So help me God...
My fellow Americans, our long national nightmare

1560.text:
is over. I have not campaigned either for
the presidency or the vice presidency. I am

1569.text:
indebted to no man, and only to one woman

1574.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: Seldom had the nation seen
a President pay such homage to his wife and

1579.text:
partner. But, they both knew the journey ahead

1583.text:
BETTY FORD: I felt that the burden and responsibilities
of assuming the role of first lady would be

1593.text:
very confining.
JANE ALEXANDER: Nixon's resignation was so

1597.text:
sudden Ford had to commute to the White House

while the Nixon's belongings were being packed
up.

1604.text:
STEVE FORD: I'll just never forget my mom
kind of standing over the stove that night

1610.text:
and cooking and doing some stuff. And the
thought of, you know, Jerry, something's wrong

1615.text:
here. You just became President of the United
States and I'm still cooking, you know I mean,

1620.text:
that was our reality. Dad's president and

JANE ALEXANDER: It was birth by fire for the
first lady. Just days after Ford became president

the King and Queen of Jordan arrived for a
long-planned state visit. Betty rose to the

1641.text:
occasion. Her reluctance and fear of assuming

1647.text:
across the dance floor.

1650.text:
blossom in the White House. It was the belated
you know kind of coming out that she had been

1657.text:
denied all these years. The Martha Graham
dancer got to showcase the arts in the White

1666.text:
House. She was a marvelous hostess, who really

1671.text:
JANE ALEXANDER: The White House parties reflected
Betty Ford's personality they were relaxed

1678.text:
and fun
It was an altogether hip new White House with

a first lady who was talking about women's
